moves.4... Nf6 5. h3 h6: Make place for the Bishop after Bf5.
moves.6. Nf3 a6: To prevent any attack against my king, because my king will stand on its' place for long.
moves.7. O-O Bf5 8. d3 e6: Open diagonal for the Bishop and for 0-0.
moves.9. Ne5: Loses another tempo. The pieces on the Queenside is very closed.
moves.9... Bd6 10. Re1: d4 is better. Now I develop the N with tempo.
moves.10... Bxe5 11. Rxe5 Nc6 12. Re1 Nd4: To worse the pawnstructure with exchange.
moves.13. Nd2 O-O: For secure the king and wait, what will do white with the N on d2, what blokades his own bishop.
moves.14. Nf3 Nxb3 15. axb3 Rc8: c2 is seems to be weak.
moves.16. Nd4 Bh7 17. Be3: ? Then on f4 stands it better.
moves.18. Ne2 d4 19. Bd2: Maybe better on c1. Now blokades the Queen.
moves.19... Qd7: Try an attack on h3 after Bf5. Whites' pieces seems to be very unmobile.
moves.20. Ng3 Rc6: Try to move over the other side - oversee the e5 pawn.
moves.21. Rc1: He was afraid of Rc8 and so didnot take my e5.
moves.21... Re8 22. Ne4 Nxe4: To open the f-file and to put with tempo my bad-bishop on f5 with attack on h3 and Rg6, Ree6 if it is necessary.
moves.26. Kh2 Bxg4: A sacrifice for open the position of whites' king and to win. Because of the bad position whites' pieces.
moves.27. hxg4 Rxg4: It is the end. Kh3-Rg6 -Kh2orh4-Qf5 and Ree6. Black is better anyway.
moves.28. Rg1: Blunder in bad position, but if I would exchange, white could be better.
